heading: 2 C. elegans plate experiment
text:
data exercise kindly supplied J. Louter (INT/ILC) derived experiment adult C.elegans nematodes exposed varying concentrations different compounds. variables RawData (outcome - number offspring counted integer value, incubation time), compName (generic name compound/chemical), compConcentration (concentration compound), expType important variables dataset.

typical analysis data run dose-response analysis using log-logistic model estimates maximal, minimal, IC50 concentration slope IC50. go details good package run computations create graphs R {drc} package.

Image 1 illustrates excel file containing data.

Image 1: Raw data file containing data C. elegans plate experiment.

file contains four sheets lots care put make-somewhat difficult read now.

Looking first five rows file:
data types variables RawData, compName compConcentration:
expected data types columns dbl, chr dbl. compConcentration however, datatype chr. means format imported incorrectly making difficult analyse data.

transforming comConcentration column dbl data plotted scatterplot graph data different compounds y-axis (RawData) varying concentrations x-axis (compConcentration). variable got colour matching compName symbol matching expType column-values.
Figure 1: Scatterplot displaying amount offspring different concentrations per compound (colour) experiment type (symbol)

data type compConcentration column changed following happened:
Figure 2: Scatterplot displaying amount offspring different concentrations per compound (colour) experiment type (symbol) compConcentration column unchanged.

Every concentration seen separate point compConcentration column ‘chr’ type.

‘correct’ graph figure 1 still cleaned . done using log10 transformation x-axis create clear graph adding jitter prevent points graph overlapping.
Figure 3: Scatterplot displaying amount offspring different concentrations per compound (colour) experiment type (symbol) transformed log10 x-axis added jitter

positive control experiments ethanol. negative control experiment S-medium.

analyze experiment learn whether indeed effect different concentrations offspring count whether different compounds different curve (IC50) take steps:

- Group data every compound. 
- Check data normally distributed. 
- Use appropriate statistical tests data see statistically significant effect different concentrations offspring count. 
- Calculate IC50 create plot curve. 
next visualization normalized data controlNegative way mean value controlNegative exactly equal 1 values expressed fraction thereof.
Figure 4: Scatterplot displaying amount offspring different concentrations per compound (colour) experiment type (symbol) normalized negative control.

took step get result relation ‘0 value’ makes easier compare samples “normal” value.
code:
# Read the excel file into a vector and display it in a small table.
scatter_FLOW.062 <- read_excel('data/data_raw/001_c_elegans_plate_exp/CE.LIQ.FLOW.062_Tidydata.xlsx') 
knitr::kable( scatter_FLOW.062 %>% head(5))
# Display the data type of select columns
scatter_FLOW.062 %>% select(RawData, compName, compConcentration) %>% head(1)## # A tibble: 1 x 3
##   RawData compName                   compConcentration
##     <dbl> <chr>                      <chr>            
## 1      44 2,6-diisopropylnaphthalene 4.99
# Transform the datatype of compConcentration to dbl
scatter_FLOW.062 <- scatter_FLOW.062 %>% transform(compConcentration = as.double(compConcentration))

# Plotting data using ggplot
scatter_FLOW.062 %>% ggplot(aes(x = compConcentration, y = RawData)) + 
  geom_point(aes(colour = compName, shape = expType)) + 
  labs(title = "Compound RawData per compound concentration",
       caption = "Data supplied by J. Louter (INT/ILC)") 
# Show example of the wrong graph from unedited .xlsx format by retrieving data
wrong_scatter_FLOW.062 <- read_excel('data/data_raw/001_c_elegans_plate_exp/CE.LIQ.FLOW.062_Tidydata.xlsx')

# Plotting data using ggplot
wrong_scatter_FLOW.062 %>% ggplot(aes(x = compConcentration, y = RawData)) + 
  geom_point(aes(colour = compName, shape = expType)) + 
  labs(title = "Compound RawData per compound concentration",
       caption = "Data supplied by J. Louter (INT/ILC)") 
# Plot data using log10 function in ggplot
scatter_FLOW.062 %>% ggplot(aes(x = compConcentration, y = RawData)) + 
  geom_point() + 
  geom_jitter(aes(colour = compName, shape = expType), width = 0.5) +
  scale_x_log10() +
  labs(title = "Compound RawData per compound concentration",
       caption = "Data supplied by J. Louter (INT/ILC)") 
# Calculate the mean of the RawData
mean_data_FLOW.062 <- scatter_FLOW.062 %>% 
  select(expType, RawData, compName, compConcentration) %>% 
  group_by(expType) %>% 
  filter(expType == 'controlNegative') %>% 
  summarise(mean_RawData = mean(RawData, na.rm = TRUE)) 

# Normalise the RawData using the calculated mean
normalized_FLOW.062 <- scatter_FLOW.062 %>% 
  select(expType, compName, compConcentration, RawData) %>%
  mutate(RawData_normalized = RawData / mean_data_FLOW.062$mean_RawData)

# Calculate the mean of the normalised data
mean_normalized_FLOW.062 <- normalized_FLOW.062 %>% group_by(expType, compName, compConcentration) %>%
  summarise(mean_RawData_normalized = mean(RawData_normalized, na.rm = TRUE))
knitr::kable(mean_normalized_FLOW.062 %>% head(5))
# Plot the normalised mean using ggplot
mean_normalized_FLOW.062 %>% ggplot(aes(x = compConcentration, y = mean_RawData_normalized)) + 
  geom_point() + 
  geom_jitter(aes(colour = compName, shape = expType), width = 0.5) +
  labs(title = "Normalized mean compound RawData per compound concentration",
       caption = "Data supplied by J. Louter (INT/ILC)")

heading: 3 Open Peer Review
text:
exercise identifying reproducibility issues scientific publication. use criteria reproducibility publicly available.
(#tab:read criteria table)Reproducibility criteriaTable clarification Transparency Criteria criteria needed score article choice. Transparency criterion comes Definition explains criterion details. descriptions particularly helpful understand criterion entails look article. Response Type actual score. Source

found open access scientific article using PubMed scored using table .

Article: Yamayoshi S, Sakai-Tagawa Y, Koga M, et al. Comparison Rapid Antigen Tests COVID-19. Viruses. 2020;12(12):1420. Published 2020 Dec 10. doi:10.3390/v12121420

Study purpose - Present 
Data availability statement - present 
Data location - Present 
Study location - Present 
Author review - present 
Ethics statement - Present 
Funding statement - Present 
Code availability - present

study rapid antigen tests (RAT) covid-19 tested corona positive patients compare effectivity PCR method. , patient material saliva nose/throat swabs used four types RATs standard PCR test. RATs also tested using 2 isolated virus strands. RATs less sensitive PCR test. RATs able detect low quantities virusparticles. big difference isolated virus clinical samples.
Data available onine .

Next used OSF website select project adresses aspect SARS-Cov-2 virus contained dataset R-code project enviorment. 
found project Bats COVID-19

code project intends compare search words ‘coronavirus’ ‘bats’ Google wikipedia multiple countries score often used together. 
readability code 4/5.

Click see full code article.

Now lets reproduce code:

Reproducibility errors: adjusted data location loaded library lubridate.

took low effort (4/5) reproduce code.

Lack pseudo coding makes data somewhat difficult interpret.
code:
### Display code chunk from bats_and_covid.R file.###
# Fig.1 (2016-2020 US Tv news about bats) 
{
  tv.dat <- 
      read.csv(file="data/data_raw/002_open_peer_review/GDELTBatsUS1620.csv")
  tv.dat$date <- ymd(tv.dat$date)
  tv.dat[61, "date"] <- "2021-01-01"
  tv.dat[61, "value"] <- NA
  tv.dat[61, "X"] <- 61
  ggplot() + 
    geom_line(data=tv.dat, aes(x=X, y=value), size=0.8, color="steelblue", linetype="solid") + 
    theme_bw() + 
    scale_x_continuous(breaks=c(1, 13, 25, 37, 49, 61), labels=c("2016", "2017", "2018", "2019", "2020", "2021")) +
    theme(axis.text.x = element_text(colour="black",size=14,angle=0,hjust=.5,vjust=.5,face="plain"),
          axis.text.y = element_text(colour="black",size=14,angle=0,hjust=1,vjust=0,face="plain"),  
          axis.title.x = element_text(colour="black",size=12,angle=0,hjust=.5,vjust=.5,face="plain"),
          axis.title.y = element_text(colour="black",size=12,angle=90,hjust=.5,vjust=.5,face="plain"),
          plot.title = element_text(size=22, face="bold")) +
    theme(strip.background =element_rect(fill="wheat")) + labs(x="", y="") +
    theme(strip.text = element_text(colour = "black", size=14, face="bold"))
}

heading: 5 Projecticum Princes Maxima Center
text:
followed minor traject ‘Data Science Biology’ Utrecht University Applied Science got externally provided projecticum case came Princess Maxima Center (PMC) Utrecht. projecticum assignment create R-shiny app containing interactive dashboard displays metadata tests run researchers PMC.
create app group first get familiar R-shiny. Luckily internet full pages use R-shiny many applications. : (“Mastering-shiny.org” n.d.) online course biggest help learning use shiny walks basics well advanced parts shiny. Another great help video: (“Shiny Rstudio tutorial,” n.d.) containing tutorial work R-shiny, cheat sheet: (“Shiny cheatsheet,” n.d.) containing useful commands use R-shiny.

learning create R-shiny applications time start working product. workflow organised agile run GitHub project board containing tasks needed complete product. tasks completed sprints occasional scrum meetings group members.

used, app ask user upload files application builds interactive dataframe. dataframe contains data points required metadata file can modified easily using dropdown menus power functions modify entire rows. Another feature interactive graph 384-well plate users can select wells exclude dataset. user done filling dataframe can press download button download TSV formatted .txt file data store locally.

process creating dashboard frequent contact representative PMC express thoughts app direction headed . ensured product user friendly actually use .great links can done using R-shiny : 
Shiny gallery great apps people made: (“Shiny Rstudio tutorial Gallery,” n.d.) 
Great app gallery: (“Shiny Rstudio Pokémon app,” n.d.)

heading: 6.1 Intro
text:
page datasets flu dengue occurrences 2002 2015 measured Google Webservices “Google Flu Trends” “Google Dengue Trends.” webservices track searches words flu dengue different countries match occurrences diseases countries. data compared “gapminder” dataset part R package dslabs.

Data Source: 
(Google sites unfortunately longer operational) 
- Google Flu Trends (http://www.google.org/flutrends) 
- Google Dengue Trends (http://www.google.org/denguetrends) 
- dslabs package

Datasets used: 
- Flu data 
- Dengue data 
- gapminder

heading: 6.2 Cleaning up
text:
comparisons can made data must tidied column types must matching. 
gapminder dataset also large includes large number years present flu dengue datasets. years also need removed dataset. 
next section show achieved:
code:
# Load the datasets into R datframes
flu_data <- read.csv('data/data_raw/005_relational_databases/flu_data.csv', skip = 11) %>% as_tibble()
dengue_data <- read.csv("data/data_raw/005_relational_databases/dengue_data.csv", skip = 11) %>% as_tibble()
gapminder <- dslabs::gapminder %>% as_tibble()

# Tidy the flu_data and dengue_data datasets
flu_data <- flu_data %>% 
  tidyr::pivot_longer(cols = Argentina:Uruguay,
                      names_to = "country", 
                      values_to = "searches"
                      )
dengue_data <- dengue_data %>% 
  tidyr::pivot_longer(cols = Argentina:Venezuela,
                      names_to = "country", 
                      values_to = "searches"
                      )

# Match the column types of the datasets
flu_data <- coltrans(flu_data)
dengue_data <- coltrans(dengue_data)

gapminder <- gapminder %>%
  transform(year = as.character(year))

# Filter gapminder to contain only the years present in the flu and dengue dataseets
gapminder <- gapminder %>% 
  filter(year %in% c(2002:2015)
         )

heading: 6.3 Using DBeaver SQL
text:
Following cleaning data, datasets need saved R uploaded DBeaver review using following commands:

Uploading files DBeaver can come handy things like: 
Using SQL shell obtain information data tables 
Using console get information data
code:
#Save the data in .csv and .rds files
write.csv(flu_data, "data/data_raw/005_relational_databases/flu_data_tidy.csv")
write.csv(dengue_data, "data/data_raw/005_relational_databases/dengue_data_tidy.csv")
write.csv(gapminder, "data/data_raw/005_relational_databases/gapminder.csv")
write_rds(flu_data, "data/data_raw/005_relational_databases/flu_data_tidy.rds")
write_rds(dengue_data, "data/data_raw/005_relational_databases/dengue_data_tidy.rds")
write_rds(gapminder, "data/data_raw/005_relational_databases/gapminder.rds")

#Upload the data to DBeaver
dbWriteTable(con, "flu_data",
             flu_data,
             overwrite = TRUE
              )
dbWriteTable(con, "dengue_data",
             dengue_data,
             overwrite = TRUE
              )
dbWriteTable(con, "gapminder",
             gapminder,
             overwrite = TRUE
              )

heading: 6.4 Joining the data
text:
Getting information tables forming something useful visualizing data can also done using R.
Data needs joined together make good informative figures. next section shows done followed preview newly formed table.
code:
# Make the data tables joinable
flu_data <- datatrans(flu_data)
dengue_data <- datatrans(dengue_data)

# Join the data tables
flu_dengue_data <- full_join(flu_data, 
                             dengue_data, 
                             by = c("country", "year"), 
                             suffix = c("_flu", "_dengue")
                             )
gap_flu_dengue_data <- inner_join(flu_dengue_data, 
                                 gapminder, 
                                 by = c("country", "year")
                                 )
knitr::kable(gap_flu_dengue_data %>% head(5))

heading: 6.5 Visualising the data
text:
data joined together one table can udes create figures:

First plotting occurrences flu dengue per region see common one region compared .

data shows dengue common South America South-Eastern Asia. also presence Central America Southern Asia much regions.

Flu appears common Eastern Europe, Western Europe Northern America. Regions ’s common North- Southern Europe South America

second graph portray occurrences flu dengue Netherlands period 2002 2015.

flu occurrences 2009 2013 least 2004 2010. flu data 2002 2003. lack data years. 
data shows Dengue occurrences Netherlands 2002 2015.

third last graph show worldwide occurrences flu dengue year year basis. Showing years diseases common.

Flu occurrences 2009, Netherlands shown previous graph. least occurrences 2002, 2003 2004. lack data years. rest datapoints show minor peaks. 
Dengue occurrences 2009 2010, least 2002, 2003 2015. also lack data first, last years survey.
code:
# plot occurrences of flu and dengue per region
flu_region <- gap_flu_dengue_data %>% ggplot() + 
  geom_col(aes(x = region, 
               y = searches_flu,
               fill = region)
           ) +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1),
        legend.position = "none"
        ) + 
  labs(title = "Flu searches per region", 
       subtitle = "Searches of the word 'Flu' per region",
       x = "",
       y = "Searches"
       )

dengue_region <- gap_flu_dengue_data %>% ggplot() + 
  geom_col(aes(x = region, 
               y = searches_dengue,
               fill = region)
           ) +
    theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1),
          legend.position = "none"
        ) + 
  labs(title = "Dengue searches per region", 
       subtitle = "Searches of the word 'Dengue' per region",
       x = "",
       y = "Searches"
       )

grid.arrange(flu_region, dengue_region, nrow = 1)
# plot occurrences of flu and dengue in the Netherlands by year
flu_region <- gap_flu_dengue_data %>% 
  filter(country == "Netherlands") %>% 
  ggplot() + 
  geom_col(aes(x = year, 
               y = searches_flu,
               fill = year)
           ) +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1),
        legend.position = "none"
        ) + 
  labs(title = "Flu searches in the Netherlands", 
       subtitle = "Searches of the word 'Flu' in the Netherlands",
       x = "Year",
       y = "Searches"
       )

dengue_region <- gap_flu_dengue_data %>% 
  filter(country == "Netherlands") %>%
  ggplot() + 
  geom_col(aes(x = year, 
               y = searches_dengue,
               fill = year)
           ) +
    theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1),
          legend.position = "none"
        ) + 
  labs(title = "Dengue searches in the Netherlands", 
       subtitle = "Searches of the word 'Dengue' in the Netherlands",
       x = "Year",
       y = "Searches"
       )

grid.arrange(flu_region, dengue_region, nrow = 1)
# plot occurrences of flu and dengue per year
flu_region <- gap_flu_dengue_data %>% ggplot() + 
  geom_col(aes(x = year, 
               y = searches_flu,
               fill = year)
           ) +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1),
        legend.position = "none"
        ) + 
  labs(title = "Flu searches per year", 
       subtitle = "Worldwide searches of the word 'Flu'",
       x = "Year",
       y = "Searches"
       )

dengue_region <- gap_flu_dengue_data %>% ggplot() + 
  geom_col(aes(x = year, 
               y = searches_dengue,
               fill = year)
           ) +
    theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1),
          legend.position = "none"
        ) + 
  labs(title = "Dengue searches per year", 
       subtitle = "Worldwide searches of the word 'Dengue'",
       x = "Year",
       y = "Searches"
       )

grid.arrange(flu_region, dengue_region, nrow = 1)

heading: 7 Parameterized data
text:
page COVID-19 case data European Center Disease Control (ECDC) used create parameterized report COVID-19 cases deaths Netherlands first data February 2020 end March 2022. February 2nd 2022 excluded range date abnormally high value. probably Dutch labs able process high number covid-PCR tests taken around date.
Information data can found 

stands graphs even though amount Covid-19 cases starts rising towards end graph amount deaths decline. due fact Delta- Omicron variants Corona virus less lethal even though caused infections spread rapidly among Dutch population. becomes evident looking data 2022. end 2021 start 2022, Omicron variant started causing rapid increase infection rate Covid-19 amount deaths time incredibly low. Especially compared number cases.
code:
# Filter the data. The first and last line change the date format so the first column can be specified as such
lct <- Sys.getlocale("LC_TIME"); Sys.setlocale("LC_TIME", "C")

data(list = params$data)
covid_data <- read_csv(params$data)
covid_data_filtered <- covid_data %>% 
  filter(countriesAndTerritories %in% "Netherlands") %>% 
  transform(dateRep = as_date(dateRep, format = "%d/%m/%Y")
            )

covid_data_filtered <- covid_data_filtered[-c(43),]

Sys.setlocale("LC_TIME", lct)
# Make ggplot containing covid cases and deaths in the Netherlands during period Jan 2021 to May 2021
cases <- covid_data_filtered %>% ggplot(aes(x = dateRep, y = cases)) +
  geom_line(colour = "blue", size = 2) +
  theme(legend.position = "none") +
    labs(title = "COVID-19 cases in the Netherlands", 
       subtitle = "Recorded COVID-19 cases in the Netherlands by date",
       x = "Month",
       y = "Cases"
       )

deaths <- covid_data_filtered %>% ggplot(aes(x = dateRep, y = deaths)) +
  geom_line(colour = "red", size = 2) +
  theme(legend.position = "none") +
    labs(title = "COVID-19 deaths in the Netherlands", 
       subtitle = "Recorded COVID-19 deaths in the Netherlands by date",
       x = "Month",
       y = "Deaths"
       )
# Plot for cases
cases
# Plot for deaths
deaths
